com.bigdata.bop.engine

Class TestQueryEngine

  • java.lang.Object
    • junit.framework.Assert
      • junit.framework.TestCase
        • junit.framework.TestCase2
          • com.bigdata.bop.engine.AbstractQueryEngineTestCase
            • com.bigdata.bop.engine.TestQueryEngine
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    junit.framework.Test

    public class TestQueryEngine
extends AbstractQueryEngineTestCase
    Test suite for the QueryEngine against a local database instance.

    Note: The BOps are unit tested separately. This test suite is focused on interactions when BOps are chained together in a query, such as a sequence of pipeline joins, a slice applied to a query, etc. 

     -Dlog4j.configuration=bigdata/src/resources/logging/log4j.properties
    Author:
    Bryan Thompson
    See Also:
    TestFederatedQueryEngine

    • Method Detail

      • getProperties

        public Properties getProperties()
        Description copied from class: TestCase2
        Reads in the configuration properties for the test from a variety of resources and returns a properties hierarchy. If a property name is not bound at the top-level of the returned Properties object, then the lower levels of the hierarchy are recursively searched.

        The hierarchy is constructed from the following properties files in the following order. The first property file in this list corresponds to the top of the property hierarchy. The last property file in this list corresponds to the bottom of the property hierarchy. The property resources are:

        1. The System properties specified using the -D argument on the command line.
        2. ${user.home}/build.properties. ${user.home} is the value of the Java system environment variable named "user.home" and corresponds to the user home directory. A warning is logged if this properties file does not exist. Note: The JUnit UI can wind up with a different value for this property than when you execute tests without the UI. It is an error if the properties file exists but can not be read.
        3. {class}.properties, where {class} is the class name reported by Java reflection, is loaded iff it is found.
        4. {class} is repeatedly truncated by dropping the last package name component to generate a package name. If a properties file named "test.properties" exists in that package then those properties are loaded.
        Overrides:
        getProperties in class TestCase2
        Returns:
        A Properties object that supplies bindings for property names according to the described hierarchy among property resources. The returned Properties is NOT cached. TODO This does not handle the recursive truncation of the class name to search for "test.properties" yet.

      • test_query_join1_without_StartOp

        public void test_query_join1_without_StartOp()
                                      throws Exception
        Test the ability run a simple join without a StartOp. An empty binding set[] is fed into the join. The join probes the index once for "Mary" and binds "Paul" when it does so. There there is one solution, which is "value=Paul".
        Throws:
        Exception

      • test_query_join1

        public void test_query_join1()
                      throws Exception
        Test the ability run a simple join. There are three operators. One feeds an empty binding set[] into the join, another is the predicate for the access path on which the join will read (it probes the index once for "Mary" and binds "Paul" when it does so), and the third is the join itself (there is one solution, which is "value=Paul").
        Throws:
        Exception

      • test_query_join1_multipleChunksIn

        public void test_query_join1_multipleChunksIn()
                                       throws Exception
        Test the ability run a simple join when multiple binding sets are submitted as the initial input. The access path associated with the join does not have any constants but the join picks up bindings from the input binding sets and uses them to constrain the access path.
        Throws:
        Exception

      • test_query_closeIterator

        public void test_query_closeIterator()
                              throws Exception
        Test verifies the ability close the iterator draining a result set before the query has finished executing and also verify that the query is correctly terminated.

        Note: This is difficult to test without having significant data scale since there is an implicit race between the consumer and the producer to close out the query evaluation, but the PipelineDelayOp can be used to impose sufficient latency on the pipeline that the test can close the query buffer iterator first.

        Note: This must also be tested in scale-out to make sure that the data backing the solutions is not discarded before the caller can use those data.

        This could be handled by: (a) materializing binding set objects out of a ByteBuffer rather than using a live decode of the data in that ByteBuffer; or by (b) using an special DirectBufferPoolAllocator.IAllocationContext which is scoped to the query results such that they are not released until the iterator draining the buffer is closed.

        Throws:
        Exception

      • test_query_slice_noLimit

        public void test_query_slice_noLimit()
                              throws Exception
        Unit test runs chunks into a slice without a limit. This verifies that the query terminates properly even though the slice is willing to accept more data.

        When the IRunningQuery implementation supports it, the source data are presented in multiple chunks in order to verify the behavior of the SliceOp across multiple (and potentially concurrent) invocations of that operator.

        Throws:
        Exception

      • test_query_slice

        public void test_query_slice()
                      throws Exception
        Run a join with a slice. The slice is always evaluated on the query controller so adding it to the query plan touches a slightly different code path from adding another join (joins are evaluated shardwise, at least in scale-out).

        Note: While the logic for visiting only the solutions selected by the slice can be tested against a mock object, the integration by which a slice halts a query when it is satisfied has to be tested against a QueryEngine.

        This must also be tested in scale-out to make sure that the data backing the solutions is not discarded before the caller can use those data. [This could be handled by materializing binding set objects out of a ByteBuffer rather than using a live decode of the data in that ByteBuffer.]

        Throws:
        Exception

      • test_query_join2_optionals

        public void test_query_join2_optionals()
                                throws Exception
        Unit test for optional join. Two joins are used and target a SliceOp. The 2nd join is marked as optional. Intermediate results which do not succeed on the optional join are forwarded to the SliceOp which is the target specified by the PipelineOp.Annotations#ALT_SINK_REF.
        Throws:
        Exception

      • test_query_join2_conditionalRoutingTrue

        public void test_query_join2_conditionalRoutingTrue()
                                             throws Exception
        Unit test for ConditionalRoutingOp. This test case tests when the condition is true (the joins are not skipped) in which case the test (and results) are essentially identical to test_query_join2().
        Throws:
        Exception

      • test_query_join2_conditionalRoutingFalse

        public void test_query_join2_conditionalRoutingFalse()
                                              throws Exception
        Unit test for ConditionalRoutingOp. This test case tests when the condition is false (the joins are skipped).
        Throws:
        Exception
